Inn Fang wrote:

> > If you want to 'unroll' the ARC into a file-per-URL, choosing
> > practical filenames for every URL can be tricky, and links
> > between files will only inconsistently work unless you do
> > fairly intrusive rewriting of the original content where necessary.
> >
> > We can't yet recommend any good tool for doing this.
> >
> > - Gordon @ IA
>
>
> Thank you very much for the replies.
>
> In this case, i think if I wish to view each harvested data, I shall
> write a program first use arcreader command to extract all
> offset numbers and file names (from url) , and loop the "arcreader
> �-offset= �" command to extract each data in ARC using the
> offset and make a copy (e.g. �� > tmp.pdf) using the file name.

Or subclass ARCReader and as its running through the records, have it 
write tmp.pdf, rather than just offsets, its default behavior.

Or use the MirrorWriterProcessor at harvest time instead of 
ARCWriterProcessor.

>
> I would like to know after Heritrix harvested the web content, how
> they are made available for public access using Wayback machine?
> What is the standard way? Extract data form ARC one by one per user
> request at Wayback machine and cache it? Or unpack the whole ARC to
> file directories for users access? Or other way?

Wayback Machine uses an index whose form is very much like the default 
output from ARCReader. URL/Date queries are run against this index. When 
comes time to display a record, the WM uses the index to find the ARC 
the wanted content resides in and the offset into the ARC at which it is 
to start gunzipping.

St.Ack

>
> Thanks!
